intro: Chenopodium triandrum, commonly known as New Zealand spinach, is a frost-sensitive, annual herb native to New Zealand. It belongs to the Amaranthaceae family and is characterized by its succulent, edible leaves that are rich in nutrients. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with alternate, lance-shaped leaves that are covered in fine hairs. It produces small, greenish flowers in clusters, followed by dry, three-angled seed capsules. This plant thrives in well-drained soils and is often cultivated as a leafy vegetable in temperate climates.
